TBA-013:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Date of procedure: [REDACTED]
Attending physician: Dr. V. Romero
Assistants: Interventional pulmonology fellow; anesthesia team; radiology technologist.

Pre-procedure diagnosis: 14 mm right lower lobe lateral basal segment nodule in a patient undergoing an early feasibility trial of pulsed electric field (PEF) ablation.
Post-procedure diagnosis: Same.
Indication: Focal nonthermal ablation of an early-stage lung cancer as part of a clinical trial in a nonsurgical candidate.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 mm endotracheal tube; ASA class III.

Procedures performed:
1. Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with cone-beam CT confirmation.
2. Transbronchial pulsed electric field ablation of right lower lobe nodule using investigational PEF catheter.

Procedure description: After standard induction, the navigation bronchoscope was advanced to the target segment. The investigational PEF catheter was introduced via an extended working channel after CT-to-body divergence correction. Cone-beam CT confirmed the catheter centered within the lesion. A series of biphasic pulsed electric field deliveries were performed per trial protocol, with multiple short pulses at pre-specified amplitudes and frequencies. No temperature rise was detected on the catheter thermistor. Post-treatment cone-beam CT showed a sharply demarcated ablation zone around the lesion without pleural disruption. Airways proximal to the treatment site appeared intact.

Estimated blood loss: <5 mL.
Complications: None immediate; no arrhythmia or hemodynamic instability during pulse delivery.
Disposition: Extubated in the operating room and monitored overnight on telemetry per protocol; follow-up imaging and trial visits scheduled.
